Graphical abstract Catalytic conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde under oxidizing conditions over VOx/ZrO2 catalysts with various surface VOx densities has been investigated. Vanadium complexes anchored on the surface of zirconia oxide support are characterized in detail and their catalytic properties reported. The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation from a peroxidic solution of ammonium metavanadate. The texture and crystallinity of the catalysts were investigated by N2 physisorption and XRD analysis. The speciation and redox properties of the vanadium complexes were studied by dispersive Raman spectroscopy and the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) method. The effects of vanadium species distribution and ZrO2 support crystallinity on the catalytic activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde were analyzed and discussed in a broad context. A comparison of the catalytic results with details of the distribution of vanadium complexes has led to the conclusion that vanadium speciation has a great impact on catalytic behavior and that small oligomeric vanadium complexes dominate in the catalysts with vanadium content slightly above half of monolayer capacity, exhibiting the highest catalytic activity and very high selectivity to acetaldehyde (better than 93%). A comparison of the catalytic behavior of VOx supported on tetragonal and monoclinic ZrO2 phases has not revealed any differences in the activity or selectivity of the ethanol ODH reaction. Long-term catalytic experiments have shown good stability of the catalysts (stable conversion and selectivity for more than 600 h). Keywords Oxidative dehydrogenation Ethanol Acetaldehyde Vanadium Zirconia 1 Introduction In recent years, the production of bioethanol has tremendously increased due to the investments in renewable energy sources motivated by the depletion of fossil fuels [1–3]. The produced bioethanol is mainly applied as a fuel or in the beverage industry. Only a small percentage of the bioethanol is utilized for producing other chemicals and hydrocarbons [3–5]. Acetaldehyde is one of the important chemicals that could be produced from bioethanol via oxidative dehydrogenation [6–11], but the heterogeneous catalyst of this reaction should be further developed for industrialization. As already mentioned, acetaldehyde is an important intermediate used for the production of various bulk chemicals, including acetic acid, acetic anhydride, ethyl acetate, peracetic acid, butanol, 2-ethylhexanol, pentaerythritol, chlorinated acetaldehydes, glyoxal, alkylamines, pyridines and others [3,10,12]. Nevertheless, this chemical can be synthesized from various starting materials, which are selected based on their price and availability. Nowadays, ethylene oxidation over PdCl2 and CuCl2 catalysts, the so-called Wacker process, is mainly used for acetaldehyde production [13,14]. Although this reaction has such advantages as the small amount of PdCl2 required for the reaction and regeneration of the catalyst, there are some drawbacks that make this reaction economically quite demanding. Among others, it is necessary to i) use corrosion-resistant materials together with expensive titanium reactor tubing and ii) purify waste air and treat wastewater in order to remove acetaldehyde, unconverted ethylene and mainly chlorinated hydrocarbons, which are highly toxic and show antimicrobial activity. Therefore, they must be treated before entering the wastewater plant to become biologically degradable. As the demand for ethylene is expected to increase further due to the increasing requirements on the production of polymers and its production may decrease due to fossil fuel depletion, it is necessary to find new and alternative processes for the production of acetaldehyde. The acetaldehyde production via the oxidative dehydrogenation (ODH) of ethanol thus appears to be a promising alternative to the Wacker process [6,15,16]. The benefits of the ODH process can be seen in the implementation of bio-based renewable raw materials, in the preservation of ethylene for the processes where it cannot easily be substituted and in the removal of some of the negative aspects of the Wacker process, such as the treatment of a large amount of wastewater and the separation and disposal of chlorinated hydrocarbons. Vanadium-containing porous solids are reported to be active heterogeneous catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation reactions of various organic compounds, namely ethanol, methanol, light alkanes and other similar compounds. A key prerequisite for increased ODH catalytic efficiency is a high number of proper vanadium oxide species on the surface. Enormous efforts have been exerted by different research groups in the search for the best support for the high dispersion of vanadium with desired surface species and in its preparation [6,10,12,17]. Previous studies have demonstrated that titania and zirconia have a higher affinity to vanadium than other conventional supports (e.g. silica or alumina) and that it is possible to achieve high dispersion of vanadium on the surface of zirconia without the possible formation of V2O5 (higher than 7 V atoms/nm2) [15,18–21]. Because of the 2D character of the complexes [22–27], the dispersed mono and polymeric vanadate species (VOx) with tetrahedral coordination are more accessible and exhibit a higher catalytic activity for the ODH reaction of ethanol than the V2O5 clusters due to the inaccessibility of a portion of vanadium atoms inside the bulk oxide clusters. Titania-supported VOx catalysts have been heavily investigated for this purpose [8,15,21,28–30], while VOx/ZrO2 catalysts have not been studied as thoroughly as titania and the conclusions have mostly been limited to the statement that zirconia-supported VOx catalysts are slightly less active than VOx/TiO2 materials. For instance, the speciation of VOx species on the surface of different phases of titania has been well studied by Fu et al., reporting that anatase is the favored phase for the formation of monomeric species [31]. For the ZrO2 crystalline phase, on the other hand, similar studies are not available. Lin et al. [32] have reported high activity of catalysts prepared through the grafting of fumed silica by Zr-alkoxide and subsequently by vanadium oxytriisopropoxide. They have observed a very suitable catalytic performance on this VOx/ZrO2/SiO2 catalyst (eight-time higher conversion and very high selectivity to acetaldehyde at temperatures below 200 °C as compared to the VOx/SiO2 catalyst). The effect of ZrO2 as an additive was more distinct than that of TiO2 used for the same purpose, especially in terms of selectivity. The formation of acetic acid over titania-supported VOx catalysts was frequently reported in the past [8,33–38]. Despite the fact that both zirconia and titania catalytic systems have been operated in the same temperature window of 150–250 °C, suitable for the formation of acetic acid [33], only a few studies [18,21,39,40] have reported the formation of acetic acid over zirconia-supported VOx catalysts. Since acetic acid is, according to Takei et al. [4], cheaper than ethanol, the low selectivity of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts to this byproduct can be an advantage of these materials over titania-supported materials. We have recently reported on the direct synthesis of the porous VOx-ZrO2 catalyst, exhibiting very high selectivity to acetaldehyde (more than 85% at all conversion degrees) and an activity comparable with the VOx/TiO2 catalytic system [6], which makes the VOx-ZrO2 system very promising. However, the study mainly focused on the investigation of the possibilities of synthesizing a high surface area porous catalytic system and not very much on the details of catalytic behavior and the role of the speciation of VOx surface complexes. It thus seems to be reasonable to investigate the VOx/ZrO2 catalytic system in more detail. The aim of the current study is to provide new information on the role of the speciation of the VOx surface complexes and of the zirconia support structure of the VOx/ZrO2-based catalysts in the activity and selectivity in ethanol ODH to acetaldehyde. For this purpose, a set of catalysts differing in vanadium content and speciation was prepared by the impregnation of amorphous ZrO2 with ammonium metavanadate. The structure and texture of the catalysts as well as the nature and properties of the surface VOx complexes were thoroughly investigated by a combination of various experimental techniques (XRD, N2 physisorption, Raman and IR spectroscopies, and H2-TPR) and tested in the ethanol ODH reaction under various experimental conditions differing in reaction temperature and contact times. Furthermore, due to the presence of various crystalline phases of ZrO2 in the catalysts and the variation of their content depending on the vanadium concentration in the catalysts, two additional ZrO2 support-based catalysts have been prepared by the calcination of the amorphous Zr(OH)4 at 400 and 700 °C, leading to the preparation of supports containing mainly tetragonal (ZrO2-400) and monoclinic (ZrO2-700) ZrO2 phases. These catalysts were characterized and tested in the same reaction under the same conditions in order to elucidate the effect of the support crystal structure in VOx/ZrO2 catalysts on their catalytic activity and selectivity. 2 Experimental 2.1 The preparation of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts VOx/ZrO2 catalysts containing various amount of vanadium were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation on amorphous ZrO2, made from Zr(OH)4 (Sigma Aldrich) by dehydration at 250 °C for 3 h, using ammonium metavanadate dissolved in hydrogen peroxide solution (with the ratio of hydrogen peroxide (30 wt. % solution) to water being 1:4) under the same conditions as the VOx/TiO2 catalyst in the previous study [10]. Briefly, 1 g of Zr(OH)4 was dehydrated and then impregnated with 1 ml of the ammonium metavanadate solution of appropriate concentration to achieve the desired vanadium content in the resulting catalyst; subsequently, it was dried at 120 °C and calcined at 450 °C for 3 h to obtain the final catalyst. The catalysts are labeled as VOx/ZrO2-X, where X is the content of vanadium in the catalyst expressed in weight percent. In order to study the effect of the ZrO2 crystalline phase on the catalytic activity of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts, the amorphous Zr(OH)4 powder was calcined at 400 and 700 °C before the impregnation procedure to obtain ZrO2 with the majority of tetragonal and monoclinic phases, respectively. These two samples were named ZrO2-400 and ZrO2-700. These supports were impregnated under the same conditions as the above-described set of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts with an appropriate amount of ammonium metavanadate to reach the concentration close to the so-called monolayer capacity (which means the surface density of vanadium of ca 7 V atoms/nm2 as reported in the literature [15,16,41]). The amount of vanadium for impregnation was determined based on the knowledge of the specific surface area of the ZrO2 supports measured by N2 adsorption. The catalysts were labeled VOx/ZrO2-400 and VOx/ZrO2-700. 2.2 The characterization of the samples The elemental composition of the investigated catalysts was determined by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) using Philips PW 1401 equipped with an Rh RTG lamp. UniQuant software was used to evaluate the results. The particle morphology of the synthesized materials was evaluated by scanning electron microscopy using a JEOL JSM-7500F instrument with a cold-cathode field emission (parameters of the measurements: 1 kV, GB high mode). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns of the investigated samples were recorded on a Philips MPD 1880 diffractometer working with the Cu Kα line (λ = 0.154 nm) in the 2θ range of 4°–70° and the 2θ scanning rate of 2.4°/min. Quantitative phase analysis of the samples was performed via the Rietveld structure refinement method employing Materials Analysis Using Diffraction (MAUD) software (Version 2.26) [42,43]. The specific surface area and the pore volume of the investigated samples were measured by means of nitrogen adsorption/desorption at the temperature of liquid nitrogen by using ASAP 2020 equipment (Micromeritics, USA). Prior to the adsorption isotherm measurement, the samples were degassed by slow heating (2 °C/min) to 250 °C, with this temperature maintained for 8 h in a vacuum generated by a turbomolecular pump. The specific surface area was calculated using the BET method. The mesopore size distribution and volume were determined by the NL DFT employing the “N2@77K” model for cylindrical pores and oxide surfaces from MicroActive data reduction software (Micromeritics, USA). Raman spectra were recorded by a DXR-Smart Raman (Thermo-scientific) instrument with Smart Excitation Laser (Thermo Scientific) with a wavelength of 780 nm in a pyrex cuvette containing powdered samples after thermal activation in vacuum. All samples were dehydrated and oxidized in the glass apparatus under static oxygen atmosphere (16–18 kPa) before the spectral measurement; the oxidation proceeded in two steps: at 120 °C for 30 min and at 450 °C for 60 min. Subsequently, the samples were cooled down to 180 °C and evacuated for 30 min. For the Raman spectra measurements, 1500 scans were performed at a resolution of 2 cm−1, with the integration time being 5 s. The laser power delivered to the sample varied depending on the vanadium concentration (max 50 mW). The spectrograph aperture was a 50-μm slit (equivalent to the laser spot diameter on the sample of approximately 3.1 μm). The H2-TPR study has been performed by an AutoChem II 2920 instrument (Micromeritics). Before the TPR experiments, the samples (100 mg) were heated to 450 °C in a flow of He (ramp rate = 15 °C/min, flow rate = 25 ml/min) and oxidized by an O2 flow (25 ml/min) at the same temperature for 1 h. After cooling to 100 °C, the samples were exposed to a flow of H2 (5% H2 in Ar with a flow rate of 25 ml/min) and the temperature was increased to 900 °C with the ramp of 10 °C/min. The changes in H2 concentration were monitored by a TCD detector. 2.3 Catalytic tests Catalytic tests were performed by Micro-activity Effi microreactor (PID Eng&Tech). The mass of the catalysts varied between 25 and 600 mg and the total flow rate of the reaction mixture was 6 l/h STP with the O2/EtOH/He = 2.5/5/92.5 M ratio. The reaction was investigated in the temperature range of 150–300 °C. The obtained products were monitored by an on-line GC instrument (Agilent 7890B). The conversion of ethanol and selectivity values toward the main reaction products were calculated according to Sachtler [44]. Turn-over-frequency (TOF, h−1) was calculated using the following equation: T O F = n n − c 0 X n − C M V m c a t w V , where n°n-c denotes the molar flow of ethanol (mol h−1), Xn-c is ethanol conversion, mcat denotes the weight of the catalyst (g), wV is the mass fraction of vanadium and MV is the atomic weight of vanadium (50.94 g mol−1). In order to investigate the effect of oxygen concentration in the reaction mixture on the catalytic activity, additional catalytic tests were performed with various oxygen concentrations (2.5, 5 and 10 vol. % in the reaction mixture) at 200 and 225 °C over the selected catalysts (VOx/ZrO2-0.5, VOx/ZrO2-5 and VOx/ZrO2-10). The weights of the catalysts were determined to achieve similar conversion values for all the catalysts studied. The total flow rate of the reaction mixture was 6 l/h STP with the composition O2/EtOH/He = x/5/(95-x). The most productive VOx/ZrO2 catalyst (VOx/ZrO2-5) was also tested in a pilot plant at the UniCRE research center (Litvinov, Czechia) (see Fig. S6 in the Supplementary Information). This long-term test was performed on 1 g of the catalyst. Before the catalytic run, the catalyst was activated by slow heating to 450 °C in the flow of 60 l/h of compressed air, and afterwards calcined at this temperature for 2 h. After that, the catalyst was cooled down to 200 °C and the gas flow was switched to a reaction mixture consisting of 92.5 mol.% of nitrogen, 2.5 mol.% of oxygen and 5 mol.% of ethanol. The flow of the reaction mixture was 60 l/h at atmospheric pressure in the reactor. The reaction was conducted continuously for 600 h. The composition of the gas mixture at the outlet of the reactor was monitored every 2 h by the online GC instruments Agilent 7890 A and Shimadzu 17-A GC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The characterization of the catalysts Fig. 1 A depicts the XRD patterns of the prepared VOx/ZrO2 samples. All samples are crystalline in character. The phase content of the samples comes from the diffractograms calculated using the Rietveld refinement procedure, and it is reported in Fig. 1B as a function of V concentration. The results indicate that the content of the tetragonal phase increases with vanadium concentration, from 12% for the VOx/ZrO2-0.5 sample to almost 100% for the catalysts with the vanadium content above 5 wt. % (Fig. 1B). These results are supported by Raman spectroscopy data (see Figs. S1 and S2 in the Supplementary Information). The skeletal vibrations visible in the Raman spectra of dehydrated samples are influenced by the population of various crystalline phases and their fraction can be calculated from the spectra. In addition, the Rietveld refinement results also indicate that the content of the amorphous phase is negligible in all samples. Our recent study of the kinetics and the crystallization mechanism in the VOx/ZrO2 system through a combination of DSC and in situ XRD has shown that vanadium markedly hinders the crystallization process, which proceeds via two independent mechanisms originating from surface defect-based active crystallization centers and from homogeneously distributed surface nuclei [45]. The presence of the VOx species formed on the grain boundaries of ZrO2 or at defect centers in the ZrO2 lattice delays the crystal growth and stabilizes the tetragonal phase. A similar observation has also been reported by Sohn et al. [23] for the same system and by Su and Bell [22] for the ZrO(OH)2 support. They have also found that the presence of V delays the crystallization of amorphous zirconia and that the transformation of tetragonal to monoclinic phase shifts to a higher temperature. The influence of vanadium content on the population of zirconium crystalline phases is also reflected in textural properties (see Fig. 2 ) and particle morphology (see Fig. 3 ). Nitrogen adsorption isotherms are reported in Fig. 2A. The corresponding calculated textural parameters (the specific surface area, the total pore volume and the maximum peak in pore-size distribution (see Fig. 2B)) are reported in Table 1 . The isotherms exhibit characteristics of type IV isotherms according to the IUPAC classification. The shape and position of hysteresis loops change with the vanadium content in the catalysts, which is also reflected in pore-size distribution curves (see Fig. 2B). The parent ZrO2 support, prepared from Zr(OH)4 by dehydration at 250 °C for 3 h in the flow of air, exhibits a surface area of 156 m2/g and pores of about 2 nm in diameter. The introduction of vanadium and calcination at 450 °C for 3 h in the flow of air has led to a decrease in the surface area and a change in porosity as a consequence of the crystallization processes. The extent and character of the changes depend on the concentration of vanadium in the catalyst. The surface area of the catalysts increases from 66 m2/g for VOx/ZrO2-0.5 to ca 120 m2/g for catalysts with the vanadium content equal to or higher than 5 wt. %. The size of the pores changed from 2 nm (observed for the parent amorphous support) to the broad distribution between 3 and 15 nm with maxima at 6–8 nm for catalysts with vanadium content lower than 5 wt. % and around 3.5 nm for catalysts with vanadium content equal to or higher than 5 wt.%. Changes in textural characteristics are also observable in the SEM images of the samples (Fig. 3). The SEM micrographs in Fig. 3 show that the particles of all samples are slightly agglomerated and the microstructure is changed with the addition of vanadium; the average particle size for the VOx/ZrO2 sample with lower vanadium content is about 20–30 nm and pore mouths with a diameter of 6–9 nm are clearly visible (see Figs. 3A and S7A–D in SI), whereas for VOx/ZrO2 catalysts with vanadium content equal to or higher than 5 wt.%, the particles are smaller than 10 nm and pore entrances are not distinguishable in the SEM images (Fig. 3 B and Fig. S7E–G in the SI), because their size is smaller than 5 nm. Garvie [46] has suggested that the stability of different ZrO2 phases is a function of crystallite size and surface energy and that a smaller crystallite size will result in tetragonal phase stabilization, while well-crystallized ZrO2 particles exhibit a monoclinic phase. This is in very good agreement with our findings. Samples with low vanadium content with a predominance of the monoclinic phase have large particles, whereas the catalysts with a predominantly tetragonal phase have significantly smaller particles. The ZrO2 supports prepared by calcination at 400 and 700 °C have also been found to exhibit crystalline character (see Fig. 1A, diffractograms h and i). Rietveld refinement calculations disclosed that the ZrO2-400 and ZrO2-700 samples contained ca 38% and 92% of the monoclinic phase, respectively (see Table 1 and Fig. 1). Textural properties and SEM images are reported in Table 1 and Figs. 2 and 3. The ZrO2-400 sample exhibited a surface area of 111 m2/g, while the ZrO2-700 sample had only 25 m2/g. This is in accordance with the observed character and size of the particles. The ZrO2-400 sample consisted of agglomerates of nanoparticles of ca 10 nm in size (Fig. 3C), whereas the ZrO2-700 sample was found to consist of large sintered particles with sizes between 20 and 50 nm and to have large voids in the structure (mimicking phase separation phenomena relying on spinodal decomposition) (Fig. 3D). Based on the known surface area, appropriate amounts of vanadium were introduced onto both supports in order to obtain catalysts with approximately monolayer coverage of the surface by vanadium (the corresponding vanadium contents were 1.5 and 6 wt. % for ZrO2-700 and ZrO2-400 supports, respectively). It has to be noted that the introduction of vanadium and the pretreatment of the resulting catalysts did not cause any significant changes in the crystalline character or textural and morphology characteristics. The nature of vanadium species on the surface of the support is very frequently investigated by Raman spectroscopy. The Raman spectra of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts in the range of VO vibrations are shown in Fig. 4 . The position of the main vibrational band is continuously shifted from 1019 cm−1 for the VOx/ZrO2-0.5 sample to 1034 cm−1 for VOx/ZrO2-10. In addition, a small shoulder is distinguishable at frequencies of 1031–1045 cm−1, shifting with the vanadium content like the main band. Apart from the typical VO vibrational band, a small band at 994 cm−1 and a broad band centered at 947 cm−1 can be observed in the spectra of VOx/ZrO2-7.5 and VOx/ZrO2-10 catalysts and samples prepared from crystalline ZrO2 supports. Based on the evidence from Raman, DR UV–vis, MAS NMR and other spectroscopic techniques, three main types of surface VOx species have been identified – isolated monomeric vanadyl complexes, polymerized vanadate species and bulk-like V2O5 species [15,16,22,23,41,47–55]. The bands above 1000 cm−1 are usually ascribed to the stretching frequency of the VO bond vibration in tetrahedrally coordinated species. The shift of the stretching frequency of the terminal VO bond vibration is caused by changes in the extent of polymerization and coordination of surface vanadium species reflected in a slight decrease of the bond angle or the strength of the bridging OVO groups [15,22,56] and an increase in dipole–dipole coupling between VO oscillators in surface VOx species with higher degrees of polymerization [19,24,57–59]. The observed changes in the Raman spectra of the dispersed surface VOx species with higher loading indicate an increasing degree of VOx species polymerization from monomeric species via small oligomeric chain-like species to progressively large polyvanadates. The systematic changes in the frequency of the VO vibrations were also confirmed by IR spectroscopy (for details, see the Supplementary Information). This means that there is only a limited number of sites on the zirconia surface at which vanadia can be dispersed in the form of monovanadate species and that oligomeric/polymeric vanadates are formed simultaneously with various populations depending on surface VOx density. The presence of a shoulder at the high-frequency side of the main VO stretching vibration band is attributable to the localization of the VOx species at different planes of the ZrO2 crystallites or to the perturbation of the vanadyl band by adjacent surface OH groups or defect sites. Recently, two VO vibrational bands, at 1020 and 1035 cm−1, have been distinguished in the Raman spectra of VOx/SiO2 and ascribed, based on normal-mode analysis, to the VO vibration with an in-phase (1020 cm−1) and an out-of-phase (1035 cm−1) character of the anchoring SiOV vibrations [25]. On the other hand, it should be noted that the vibrational behavior of vanadia on silica and other supports can be significantly different due to very close frequencies of VOx vibration with silica phonons leading to vibrational coupling as proven by normal-mode analysis [57,60,61], whereas such coupling can be less important in the system of VOx/ZrO2. The band at 994 cm−1 is indisputably related to the presence of small V2O5 clusters. This band appears at the vanadium loading of 7.5 wt. %, but it is missing in the spectrum of the VOx/ZrO2-10 catalyst, where the band appears at 947 cm−1. Based on a comparison with the Raman spectrum of a referent compound, the band at 947 cm−1 has recently been ascribed to the presence of the ZrV2O7 compound [6]. This is in agreement with the observation that ZrV2O7 is formed only when V2O5 is present and not in the presence of dispersed VOx species alone, because ZrV2O7 is formed as a consequence of ZrO2 migration into V2O5 crystallites rather than by the reverse process [22]. Therefore, the content of vanadium in the VOx/ZrO2-7.5 catalyst is close to the monolayer capacity and further addition of vanadium to the VOx/ZrO2-10 catalyst already exceeds the monolayer capacity (also supported by the close to full disappearance of zirconia OH group vibrations in the IR spectra of the dehydrated catalysts (see Fig. S3 in the Supplementary Information)). This should lead to the formation of V2O5, which, however, reacts with zirconia during calcination and is transformed into ZrV2O7. In addition, both catalysts prepared from the crystalline ZrO2 supports (VOx/ZrO2-400 and VOx/ZrO2-700) exhibit a small amount of V2O5 clusters, which is in line with our intention to prepare close to monolayer catalysts. In the present study, the redox properties of the vanadium species were investigated by hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR). Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles of the VOx/ZrO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . All samples have exhibited only one asymmetric reduction peak in the temperature range of 350–600 °C. The temperatures of the maxima of the reduction peaks (Tmax) change with vanadium loading (see Table 1). It has been observed that the Tmax values decrease from 486 °C for the VOx/ZrO2-0.5 catalyst to 459 °C for the VOx/ZrO2-2.5 catalyst and then start to increase with further vanadium loading up to 519 °C for VOx/ZrO2-10. A comparison with the TPR profiles of the pure V2O5 and ZrV2O7 compounds (see Fig. S5 in the Supplementary Information) reveals that the supported vanadium oxide catalysts reduce at much lower temperature than bulk vanadium pentoxide and zirconium pyrovanadate. Similar characteristics of the TPR profiles of vanadia/zirconia systems were provided previously in literature [48,62–71]. The TPR data (especially the position of the reduction peaks on the temperature scale) are strongly influenced by experimental conditions (flow rates, heating rates, hydrogen concentration in the reduction gas, the content of impurities – especially traces of water vapor, sample mass, contact time with reduction gas etc.) [72]. Nevertheless, this technique is very helpful in the characterization of the reducibility of different species in the active phase of the catalyst even if the information obtained is merely comparable and more general trends than the exact temperature values need to be taken into account. For example, Adamski et al. [67] observed in the TPR profiles of V2O5/ZrO2 that the TPR peaks first shifted to lower temperatures at increasing vanadium concentrations and then moved back toward higher temperatures. These shifts in the maxima of the reduction peaks are usually interpreted as a change in the reducibility of different vanadium surface species. On the basis of a comparison of TPR profiles with the information from vanadium complex speciation obtained from complementary spectroscopic techniques, it has been concluded that small polymeric species are reduced by hydrogen faster and at lower temperatures than monovanadate complexes and larger polymeric species. [66] Deo and Wachs have proposed the reducibility sequence as follow: VOV > VO(V)2 > VO. [68] Therefore, we can conclude that the small polyvanadates (or oligomeric species) generated on the VOx/ZrO2 catalyst with a surface density around 3.4 V atoms/nm2 exhibit the lowest reduction temperature in H2-TPR, which makes them the most easily reducible species by hydrogen in our catalysts. The amount of hydrogen consumed during the reduction of VOx species increases with vanadium content, but it is smaller than the theoretical value assuming quantitative reduction from V(V) to V(III) (see Table 1). It is possible to interpret this observation as an interplay between the following circumstances: (i) some vanadium atoms were not reduced to the oxidation state V(III) during the TPR experiment, (ii) some vanadium atoms were not in oxidation state V(V) after pretreatment for various reasons or (iii) a part of vanadium was not accessible for the gaseous hydrogen as it had been submerged into the zirconia during the transformation and crystallization processes. 3.2 Catalytic tests A typical dependence of the conversion and selectivity values of the ethanol ODH reaction on the increasing temperature can be illustrated on the 100 mg of a sample VOx/ZrO2-5 catalyst (depicted in Fig. 6 ). The data indicate that the conversion of ethanol is greatly enhanced with increasing temperature (from 10% at 175 °C to 78% at 300 °C), while the selectivity toward acetaldehyde as the main reaction product is slightly reduced from 99% at 175 °C to 92% at 300 °C. The selectivity to the main reaction product acetaldehyde – is considerable even at 300 °C, whereas a decline of selectivity at higher temperature is usually reported for similar catalysts in the literature [21,40]. According to some studies, this can be caused by oxygen-rich conditions; our study, on the other hand, applies the stoichiometric ethanol/oxygen ratio (assuming selective oxidation of ethanol exclusively to acetaldehyde). The other products of the reaction were ethene, diethylether and, at temperatures above 200 °C, carbon oxides. The changes in selectivity to ethene (increase with temperature) and diethylether (the flat maximum and decrease at higher temperatures) (see Fig. 6, curves d and e) are more likely to be caused by the increase in the conversion degree rather than being a direct consequence of the temperature changes. Both compounds are formed via an acid–base catalytic mechanism [4,9,73] and the water vapor formed in the reaction strongly influences the concentration of surface acid sites. Moreover, the intermolecular dehydration to diethylether becomes a less likely reaction step as the conversion degree of ethanol increases in comparison with the intramolecular ethene formation. No formation of acetic acid has been observed for any sample tested under any conditions, contrary to the results reported by Andrushkevich et al. [21]. This can be caused by the application of different experimental conditions. Andrushkevich et al. [21] used 5 vol. % of ethanol and 20 vol. % of oxygen, i.e. oxygen-rich conditions. On the other hand, we applied a stoichiometric amount of oxygen related to selective conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde (i.e. half the molar amount of ethanol), which means that our experiments were carried out under oxygen-lean conditions. For further investigation of the vanadium content (the coverage and speciation of the VOx surface complex effect), catalytic tests at various contact times (catalyst loading was changed from 25 to 600 mg) were carried out at temperatures of 175, 200 and 225 °C. The experimental conditions of low conversion degree (>30%) and high acetaldehyde selectivity (>90%) were selected to avoid the influence of subsequent reactions steps and effects caused by the abatement of the reaction compounds. The isoconversion selectivity toward individual products, the apparent activation energy of the reaction and the turn-over-frequency (TOF) of all investigated catalysts are summarized in Table 2 and represented in Figs. 7 and 8 . The TOF values, calculated from catalytic data with the presumption that all vanadium atoms are accessible for the reactants and active in the reaction, are greatly affected by the vanadium concentration and thus also by the distribution of the individual types of VOx surface complexes (see Table 2 and Fig. 7). The highest TOF values are obtained for moderate vanadium concentrations between 2.5 and 5 wt. % of vanadium, which corresponds to the vanadium surface density slightly lower than monolayer coverage. Tetrahedrally coordinated oligomeric VOx species are typical surface VOx complexes below the monolayer and they have recently been suggested as possible active catalytic sites for ethanol oxidation [19,21]. The characterization of the vanadium surface species by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 4) and H2-TPR (Fig. 5) clearly indicate that the character and properties of the tetrahedrally coordinated VOx species present in the catalysts are significantly different. The low TOF values for samples with the low vanadium content (0.5–1.5%) indicate that the presence of the monomeric VOx species on the ZrO2 surface is undesirable for the partial oxidation of ethanol. The lower activity of these samples can be ascribed to their redox properties because the samples with low vanadium concentration (i.e. containing a high amount monomeric VOx species) exhibit a shift of the maximum TPR profiles (Fig. 5) to higher temperatures as compared to the TPR profiles of the samples exhibiting the highest TOF values. This indicates that the superior oxygen exchange capability of the catalyst is necessary for obtaining better performance of the catalyst (in accordance with Ref. [74]). Differences in the redox properties of the VOx species are also evidenced by changes in apparent activation energies of the ODH reaction. The previously published value of activation energy for the reoxidation of silica-supported VOx is approximately 40 kJ/mol [75], and values in the range of 80–120 kJ/mol have been published [19,76,77] for the activation energy of the βCH bond splitting, which is the rate-limiting step leading to the formation of acetaldehyde from adsorbed ethoxy species. The lower values of apparent activation energy (Fig. 7 and Table 2) for samples with the low vanadium content thus indicate that the rate of catalyst reoxidation can play a more significant role in the kinetics of the partial oxidation of ethanol for samples with the low vanadium content (and a higher content of monomeric units) than for samples containing a higher amount of oligomeric or polymeric VOx species, where the activation energy values of ca 70 kJ/mol are closer to ethanol activation energy values. On the other hand, the presence of clusters of V2O5 or ZrV2O7, clearly evidenced by Raman spectra (Fig. 4) for samples containing more than 5 wt. % of vanadium, could also affect the catalyst activity due to diffusion and kinetic limitations or a limited number of surface vanadium atoms accessible for the reactant in the bulk clusters, which results in the reduction of TOF values for samples with 7.5 and 10 wt. % of vanadium. In order to investigate the effect of oxygen concentration in the reaction mixture on the catalytic activity, additional catalytic tests were performed with various oxygen concentrations (2.5, 5 and 10 vol. % in the reaction mixture) at 200 and 225 °C over the selected catalysts (VOx/ZrO2-0.5, VOx/ZrO2-5 and VOx/ZrO2-10) and apparent activation energies and reaction orders for oxygen were calculated from the results obtained (see Table 3 ). It is evident that ethanol conversion increases with increasing oxygen concentration, but the changes are not dramatic. This is also reflected in low reaction orders for oxygen, specifically 0.2–035, which are in good agreement with previously published reaction order values for oxygen [19,78]. In addition, the effect of oxygen concentration is more pronounced in the case of catalysts with higher vanadium content. No carbon oxides and no acetic acid were detected even at the highest oxygen concentration. Only a negligible amount of ethene and small amounts of diethylether (selectivity up to 2%) were observed in the outlet gas. Selectivity to acetaldehyde reached 98.7–99.7% for all three catalysts. It is evident that apparent activation energy increases with increasing oxygen concentration in the reaction mixture in all cases, but distinctly in the case of catalysts with higher vanadium content. While the activation energy remains at about 60 kJ/mol for the VOx/ZrO2-0.5 catalyst, for the catalysts VOx/ZrO2-5 and VOx/ZrO2-10, the activation energy increases to 100–110 kJ/mol. This demonstrates that re-oxidation is a rate-limiting step in the case of catalysts with low vanadium content (where monomeric species prevail), whereas CH splitting is a rate-determining step in ethanol oxidation over highly loaded catalysts. It is worth mentioning that the catalysts exhibiting the highest TOF values fall within the range of vanadium concentrations in which the dominance varies between monoclinic and tetragonal phases (see Fig. 1B). Therefore, it is entirely legitimate to ask whether the changes in the TOF values are caused by the change of the crystalline modification of the support demonstrated by XRD analysis (Fig. 1B) and Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S2 in the Supplementary Information) or by the change in the degree of VOx species polymerization and reducibility proven by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 4) and H2-TPR (Fig. 5). To understand whether or how the ZrO2 crystalline phase content could affect the catalytic activity, two additional ZrO2 support-based catalysts containing mainly tetragonal (VOx/ZrO2-400) and monoclinic (VOx/ZrO2-700) ZrO2 phases were prepared by the calcination of the Zr(OH)4 precursor at 400 and 700 °C, followed by impregnation with vanadium using the same procedure as in the case of all VOx/ZrO2 catalysts in this study. The presented data clearly indicate that TOF values for VOx/ZrO2-400 and VOx/ZrO2-700, which are catalysts with the vanadium content close to the VOx monolayer coverage of the ZrO2 support surface, remain unchanged due to the phase content of ZrO2 support (the two rightmost points in Fig. 7), i.e. the phase of the ZrO2 does not influence the activity of oxovanadium species in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol. This is rather surprising, because various reactions exhibited differences in the catalytic activities of the individual crystalline ZrO2 phases. It has recently been reported for bioethanol steam reforming that the tetragonal phase of zirconia is favored for the high stability and selectivity of the catalyst prepared [17]. Furthermore, a Pt/WOx-ZrO2 catalyst with a prevailing tetragonal ZrO2 phase exhibited high n-butane isomerization activity [79]. On the other hand, a monoclinic ZrO2 support exhibited higher activity in the phenol alkylation over V2O5/ZrO2 catalysts [65] and methanol synthesis over Cu/ZrO2 [80]. This may be caused by the different basicity of the surface sites, as indicated by an IR spectroscopic study of CO and CO2 adsorption on both polymorphs [81]. Despite the significant difference in the population of both ZrO2 crystalline forms, both catalysts exhibit the same activity at all investigated temperatures (see Fig. 7). In addition, the highest TOF values reached for VOx/ZrO2-2.5 and -5 catalysts are comparable with the TOF values obtained for VOx/ZrO2-400 and VOx/ZrO2-700 samples at all investigated temperatures. This indicates that most of the vanadium introduced into VOx/ZrO2 catalysts prepared from the amorphous support (prepared by drying the Zr(OH)4 precursor) is accessible for the reaction and thus the preparation procedure and the crystallization process taking place in the material during calcination do not cause the immersion of the significant portion of vanadium into the volume of the support during the catalyst calcination. Therefore, the changes in TOF observed within the VOx/ZrO2 catalyst concentration set are caused by the different population of VOx complexes in individual catalysts. Isoconversion selectivity data are presented in Fig. 8 and Table 2 for the three tested temperatures (175, 200 and 225 °C) and the constant conversion degree of ethanol (5, 10 and 20%). The obtained results clearly show that the measured isoconversion selectivities to ethene and diethylether slightly increase (from 0.3 to ca 0.6% for ethene, and from 0.5 to ca 2.5% for diethylether) with the increase in vanadium concentration. Both ethene and diethylether are produced by an acid–base catalysis mechanism [4,9,73] and selectivity to both is most likely affected by a change in the acid–base character of the catalyst surface, where more acidic vanadium oxide replaces the ZrO2 surface (the zero charge point (ZCP) of V2O5≈1.4, the ZCP of ZrO2≈6.7 [82]). As mentioned above, the temperature dependence of the selectivity for both mentioned byproducts under isoconversion conditions is weak at least for low conversion degree values, confirming our previously mentioned assumption of only an indirect effect of temperature on the selectivity to these compounds via changes of ethanol conversion. The isoconversion selectivity to acetaldehyde slightly decreases with increasing vanadium content for temperatures of 175 and 200 °C as the selectivity toward ethene and diethylether increases. At 225 °C, the selectivity to acetaldehyde exhibits a maximum for the VOx/ZrO2-2.5 sample. The lower values of selectivity to acetaldehyde for the samples with low vanadium content are caused by the overoxidation of ethanol to carbon oxides as it is presented in Fig. 8. The higher selectivity of the catalysts with lower vanadium content to carbon oxides is in good agreement with the more significant influence of the reoxidation step on the kinetics of reaction observed over these catalysts (as discussed in the previous paragraph). The reason for the higher selectivity to carbon oxides on the samples with higher concentration of monomeric species is not clear and we can only speculate that it can be caused either by the longer persistence of the adsorbed reaction intermediate on the ZrOH and monomeric VOx sites or by the participation of very unselective surface oxygen radical species appearing during the reoxidation process of reduced monomeric VOx sites. The selectivity to the main reaction product observed for VOx/ZrO2-400 and VOx/ZrO2-700 samples impregnated on the reference monoclinic and tetragonal ZrO2 supports is comparable to the VOx/ZrO2 sample with similar VOx surface density. Despite the observed changes, the absolute values of the selectivity to acetaldehyde are still remarkable and exceed 90% for all the samples tested. The highest productivity expressed as the mass of the desired product (acetaldehyde) per unit mass of the catalyst and one hour (i.e. the yield divided by space time) was exhibited by the VOx/ZrO2-5 catalyst, specifically 1.69 gAA/gcat/h. This most productive catalyst (VOx/ZrO2-5) was also tested in a pilot plant for a longer time on stream (TOS = 600 h) to determine its stability; the obtained results of selectivity and conversion are depicted in Fig. 9 . It can be observed that the catalyst exhibits a quite stable activity for the first 50 h (ca 50% conversion of ethanol), but its selectivity to products changes; acetaldehyde selectivity decreases to 83% with a simultaneous increase in selectivity to ethene and diethylether. After that, the acetaldehyde selectivity starts to increase again slowly to 99%, whereas the selectivity to ethene and diethylether decreases to 1% and 0%, respectively. At the same time, conversion first decreases from 50% to 35% at 170 h of TOS and then starts to increase. After approximately 200 h on the stream, the catalyst was stabilized and the conversion and selectivity remained almost constant for another 400 h. The catalyst in steady state exhibits conversion of ca 46% with 99% selectivity to acetaldehyde. The instability of the selectivity and conversion values in the initial step (first 200 h) could be attributed to the formation of coke in few active sites of the catalyst or to the change in the reduction degree. After the catalyst spent 600 h on the stream, it was characterized by XRD, N2 adsorption isotherm, Raman and IR spectroscopy, and TG. The results showed that the amount of coke in the steady-state catalyst was below 1 rel. % of mass, with no changes in crystallinity or textural properties detected. It can be concluded that the VOx/ZrO2 system is a promising and interesting catalytic material for the conversion of ethanol to more valuable acetaldehyde. 4 Conclusion A systematic investigation into the physico-chemical properties of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts and their catalytic performance in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde herein make it possible to draw the following conclusions: - The catalytic activity of the VOx/ZrO2 catalysts is heavily dependent on the nature and population of surface VOx complexes. The highest activity is exhibited by oligomeric (small polymeric) vanadate surface complexes dominating on the surface of the catalysts with vanadium content above half of monolayer capacity. Monomeric VOx species exhibit low catalytic activity, probably due to the slow reoxidation of the active species as evidenced by the low apparent activation energy of the reaction. Catalysts with vanadium content close to or above monolayer capacity suffer from the presence of vanadium pentoxide and/or zirconium vanadate clusters, having low activity mainly due to the inaccessibility of a significant part of vanadium atoms buried inside the clusters. The oligomeric VOx species thus exhibit the highest catalytic activity. The highest TOF values correlate with the lowest temperature for the reduction of VOx species by hydrogen in H2-TPR patterns, indicating high reducibility of these species and easy re-oxidation under reaction conditions. This is also supported by high apparent activation energy, corresponding to the CH splitting step of the reaction mechanism. - A comparison of the catalytic performance of the VOx/ZrO2 catalysts prepared from ZrO2 supports with prevailing tetragonal and monoclinic phases has revealed that both ZrO2 supports covered by a monolayer of the VOx species exhibit almost identical catalytic activity, unlike many other reactions. - All VOx/ZrO2 catalysts exhibit very high selectivity to acetaldehyde (above 90% in all cases). Reaction by-products include the products of intermolecular and intramolecular ethanol dehydration (i.e. ethene and diethylether), and above 200 °C also carbon oxides as products of ethanol overoxidation. Ethanol ODH over VOx/ZrO2 catalysts has not produced any acetic acid or other oxygenates. - Long-term experiments carried out on the VOx/ZrO2-5 catalysts, exhibiting the highest productivity of acetaldehyde, have shown a good stability of the catalysts for more than 600 h. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde under oxidizing conditions over VOx/ZrO2 catalysts with various surface VOx densities has been investigated. Vanadium complexes anchored on the surface of zirconia oxide support are characterized in detail and their catalytic properties reported. The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation from a peroxidic solution of ammonium metavanadate. The texture and crystallinity of the catalysts were investigated by N2 physisorption and XRD analysis. The speciation and redox properties of the vanadium complexes were studied by dispersive Raman spectroscopy and the temperature programmed reduction (TPR) method. The effects of vanadium species distribution and ZrO2 support crystallinity on the catalytic activity in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethanol to acetaldehyde were analyzed and discussed in a broad context. A comparison of the catalytic results with details of the distribution of vanadium complexes has led to the conclusion that vanadium speciation has a great impact on catalytic behavior and that small oligomeric vanadium complexes dominate in the catalysts with vanadium content slightly above half of monolayer capacity, exhibiting the highest catalytic activity and very high selectivity to acetaldehyde (better than 93%). A comparison of the catalytic behavior of VOx supported on tetragonal and monoclinic ZrO2 phases has not revealed any differences in the activity or selectivity of the ethanol ODH reaction. Long-term catalytic experiments have shown good stability of the catalysts (stable conversion and selectivity for more than 600 h).
coredata.dc:title: The effect of vanadium content and speciation on the activity of VOx/ZrO2 catalysts in the conversion of ethanol to acetaldehyde
